concise_definition: v. 欺骗, 误导, 欺诈

definitions.explanation_en: To cause someone to believe something that is not true, often through deliberate manipulation, false information, or concealment of facts, with the intent to gain an advantage or avoid consequences.
definitions.explanation_cn: 通过故意的操纵、虚假信息或隐瞒事实，使他人相信不真实的事情，通常是为了获取利益或逃避责任。
definitions.example_en: He deceived his investors by fabricating financial reports.
definitions.example_cn: 他通过伪造财务报告欺骗了投资者。

definitions.explanation_en: To mislead or trick someone, sometimes subtly or through appearances, even if no direct lie is told.
definitions.explanation_cn: 通过表象或微妙手段误导或愚弄他人，即使没有直接说谎。
definitions.example_en: The mirror deceived her into thinking the room was larger than it actually was.
definitions.example_cn: 这面镜子误导了她，让她以为房间比实际要大。

definitions.explanation_en: To fail to meet expectations by appearing to be one thing while being another, often resulting in disappointment or betrayal.
definitions.explanation_cn: 表面上看似如此，实则不然，从而未能达到预期，常导致失望或背叛感。
definitions.example_en: The charming salesman deceived us into buying a faulty product.
definitions.example_cn: 这位魅力十足的销售员骗我们买了一个有故障的产品。

comparison.analysis: “Lie” (说谎) 指直接说出虚假的陈述，是一种明确的语言行为；而 “deceive” 更广泛，可以不通过言语，仅通过行为、隐瞒或误导实现，其手段更隐蔽、更复杂。
“Mislead” (误导) 与 “deceive” 非常接近，常可互换，但 “mislead” 更强调无意或间接导致错误理解，有时不带有恶意；而 “deceive” 通常隐含蓄意欺骗的意图，道德色彩更负面。
“Trick” (耍花招) 通常指使用具体的计谋、诡计或小把戏来欺骗，常带有狡猾或恶作剧的意味，语义较轻，有时甚至用于非恶意情境（如魔术师 trick the audience）；而 “deceive” 更正式、更严重，常用于涉及信任、道德或法律后果的语境。
